newsitem.title: GERMANY: Waigel says euro must be stable as Deutschemark.
newsitem.headline: Waigel says euro must be stable as Deutschemark.

text.p: German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said on Saturday that Europe's planned single currency would only be launched if it was as stable as the Deutschemark.

Commenting on a running battle between members of his Christian Social Union (CSU) party and Chancellor Helmut Kohl over the prospects of a soft euro, Waigel said he and the CSU still support a stable euro and that their position was unchanged.
Speaking to reporters at a meeting of his CSU party, Waigel said that delaying economic and monetary union (EMU) would only lead to confusion on financial markets and cost Germany dearly.

Edmund Stoiber, the Bavarian premier and Waigel's rival in the CSU, has waged a vocal campaign against any attempt by Bonn to agree to soften the fiscal criteria set out in the Maastricht treaty for entry into EMU.

Speculation has grown that some leeway on the key deficit limit of three percent of gross domestic product could be granted after France said this week that it would not meet the target this year, the crunch year for qualifying for EMU.
A leading CSU member has even warned that the Bavarian sister party to Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union (CDU) could leave the ruling coalition over the issue.
